channel.title: The Hon. John McCain
channel.description: The Hon. John McCain U.S. Senator of Arizona (Remarks as Prepared for Delivery)

item.title: Thank you.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: It's an honor, as always, my fellow Republicans, to join you at our national convention, and add my voice to yours as we nominate the next president of the United States, my friend, Governor Mitt Romney.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: I had hopes once of addressing you under different circumstances. But our fellow Americans had another plan four years ago, and I accept their decision.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: I've been blessed for so long to play a role in our nation's affairs that I'm conscious only of the debt I owe America, and I thank you for the honor.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: When we nominate Mitt Romney, we do so with a greater purpose than winning an advantage for our party.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: We charge him with the care of a higher cause. His election represents our best hopes for our country and the world.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: It is said this election will turn on domestic and economic issues. But what Mitt Romney knows, and what we know, is that our success at home also depends on our leadership in the world.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: It is our willingness to shape world events for the better that has kept us safe, increased our prosperity, preserved our liberty and transformed human history.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: At our best, America has led.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: We have led by our example, as a shining city on a hill. We have led at the direction of patriots from both parties. We have led, shoulder to shoulder, with steadfast friends and allies. We have led by giving voice to the voiceless, insisting that every human life has dignity and aiding those brave souls who risk everything to secure the inalienable rights that are endowed to all by our Creator.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: We have led with generous hearts, moved by an abiding love of justice, to help others eradicate disease, lift themselves from poverty, live under laws of their own making and determine their own destinies.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: We have led, when necessary, with the armed might of freedom's defenders.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: And always we have led from the front, never from behind.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: This is what makes America an exceptional nation: It is not just a matter of who we are, it is the record of what we have done.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: It is the responsibility that generation after generation of Americans has affirmed and carried forward.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: It is the cause that many Americans have sacrificed everything -- absolutely everything -- to defend.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: And when they have gone into battle, as they do today, they have done so with the conviction that the country that sent them there is worth their sacrifice, that it stands for something more than the sum of our individual interests.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: May God bless all who have served, and all who serve today, as He has blessed us with their service.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: We are now being tested by an array of threats that are more complex, more numerous and just as deadly as any I can recall in my lifetime. We face a consequential choice -- and make no mistake, it is a choice.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: We can choose to follow a declining path, toward a future that is dimmer and more dangerous than our past.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: Or we can choose to reform our failing government, revitalize our ailing economy and renew the foundations of our power and leadership in the world.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: That is what's at stake in this election.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: Unfortunately, for four years, we've drifted away from our proudest traditions of global leadership -- traditions that are truly bipartisan. We've let the challenges we face, both at home and abroad, become harder to solve.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: We can't afford to stay on that course any longer. We can't afford to cause our friends and allies -- from Latin America to Asia, Europe to the Middle East, and especially in Israel, a nation under existential threat -- to doubt America's leadership.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: We can't afford to give governments in Russia and China a veto over how we defend our interests and the progress of our values in the world.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: We can't afford to have the security of our nation and those who bravely defend it endangered because their government leaks the secrets of their heroic operations to the media.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: I believe we can't afford to substitute a political timetable for a military strategy.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: By committing to withdraw from Afghanistan before peace can be achieved and sustained, the president has discouraged our friends and emboldened our enemies, which is why our commanders did not recommend that decision and why they have said it puts our mission at greater risk.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: We can't afford another $500 billion in cuts to our defense budget -- on top of the nearly $500 billion in cuts that the president is already making. His own secretary of defense has said that cutting our military by nearly $1 trillion would be "devastating."
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: And yet, the president is playing no leadership role in preventing this crippling blow to our military.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: A wise congressman from Wisconsin has said, "Our fiscal policy and our foreign policy are on a collision course." And that man is our next vice president, Paul Ryan.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: But most of all, we can't afford to abandon the cause of human freedom. When long-suffering peoples demand liberation from their jailers and torturers and tyrants, the leader of the free world must stand with them.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: Unfortunately, this is not happening.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: When Iranians rose up by the millions against their oppressive rulers, when they beseeched our president, chanting in English, "Are you with us, or are you with them?", when the entire world watched as a brave young woman named Neda was shot and bled to death in a street in Tehran.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: The president missed a historic opportunity to throw America's full moral support behind an Iranian revolution that shared one of our highest interests: ridding Iran of a brutal dictatorship that terrorizes the Middle East and threatens the world.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: The situation is far worse in Syria. What began as peaceful protests has now become, 18 months later, a savage and unfair fight.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: With the full backing of Iran, and Hezbollah, and Russia--with tanks, and helicopters, and fighter jets, Bashir Assad is murdering men, women and children. More than 20,000 people have perished. Extremists are gaining ground. And the conflict is becoming more dangerous by the day for our allies, and for us.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: In other times, when other courageous people fought for their freedom against sworn enemies of the United States, American presidents -- both Republicans and Democrats -- have acted to help them prevail.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: Sadly, for the lonely voices of dissent in Syria, and Iran, and elsewhere, who feel forgotten in their darkness, and sadly for us, as well, our president is not being true to our values.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: For the sake of the cause of freedom, for the sake of people who are willing to give their lives so their fellow citizens can determine their own futures and for the sake of our nation -- the nation founded on the idea that all people, everywhere, have the right to freedom and justice -- we must return to our best traditions of American leadership, and support those who face down the brutal tyranny of their oppressors and our enemies.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: Across the world, people are seizing control of their own destinies. They are liberating themselves from oppressive rulers. And they want America's support.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: They want America's assistance as they struggle to live in peace and security, to expand opportunity for themselves and their children, to replace the injustices of despots with the institutions of democracy and freedom.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: America must be on the right side of history.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: The demand for our leadership in the world has never been greater. People don't want less of America.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: They want more.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: Everywhere I go in the world, people tell me they still have faith in America.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: What they want to know is whether we still have faith in ourselves.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: I trust that Mitt Romney has that faith, and I trust him to lead us.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: I trust him to affirm our nation's exceptional character and responsibilities.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: I trust him to know that our security and economic interests are inextricably tied to the progress of our values.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: I trust him to know that if America doesn't lead, our adversaries will, and the world will grow darker, poorer and much more dangerous. I trust him to know that an American president always, always, always stands up for the rights, and freedoms, and justice of all people.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: I trust Mitt Romney to know that good can triumph over evil, that justice can vanquish tyranny, that love can conquer hate, that the desire for freedom is eternal and universal, and that America is still the best hope of mankind.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain

item.title: And now, my fellow Americans: Let's elect our next commander-in-chief, and the next leader of the free world, my friend, Governor Mitt Romney.
item.author: The Hon. John McCain
